member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.RMatrix.Min
member.returns: Min value or NaN, if there is no valid value.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.RMatrix.Max
member.returns: Max value or NaN, if there is no valid value.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.RMatrix.LS
member.summary: Calculates Least-Squares Transformation of the matrix. NOTE: result is square symmetric matrix.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.RMatrix.Inversed
member.summary: Calculates inversed matrix. NOTE: For square matrices only. If inversed matrix does not exist - returns NaN matrix. WARNING: Algorithm uses Matrix class to implement function so, it is slow because data copied twice.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.RMatrix.PInversed
member.summary: Calculates Pseudo-Inversed Matrix (for rectangular) NOTE: suppose that rows are linear independant pinv(A)=A'(AA')^-1 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_inverse)

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.RMatrix.Determinant
member.summary: Calculates determinant. NOTE: for square matrices only. WARNING: Algorithm uses Matrix class to implement function so, it is slow because data copied twice.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.RMatrix.Adjoint
member.summary: Calculates Adjoint Matrix NOTE: for square matrices only. WARNING: Algorithm uses Matrix class to implement function so, it is slow because data copied twice.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.RMatrix.Condition
member.summary: Condition number of the matrix (using L2 norm)

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.RMatrix.Trace
member.summary: Trace of the matrix (for SQUARE only)

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.RMatrix.Difference(System.Int32,Mathematics.LA.RMatrix)
member.summary: Finite Differnce. Note: number Rows/Columns reduced by 1. direct - direction 1 - by rows, 2 - by columns.

member.name: T:Mathematics.LA.LES
member.summary: Linear Equation System (static class for low-level operations).

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.LES.Gauss(System.Double[][],System.Double[],System.Double[]@)
member.summary: Gauss' method. NOTE: source data copied to make triangle matrix so, primary data not changed.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.LES.GaussPartialPivoting(System.Double[][],System.Double[],System.Double[]@)
member.summary: Gauss' method with partial pivoting. NOTE: source data copied to make triangle matrix so, primary data not changed.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.LES.GaussCompletePivoting(System.Double[][],System.Double[],System.Double[]@)
member.summary: Gauss' method with complete pivoting. NOTE: source data copied to make triangle matrix so, primary data not changed.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.LES.LUExpansion(System.Int32,System.Double[][]@,System.Double[][]@,System.Int32[]@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: LU. NOTE: source matrix not copied so, primary data changed. if LU is null, new memory allocated.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.LES.RunMethod(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[]@)
member.summary: Solving three-diagonal system c[0]y[0] +b[0]y[1] = f[0] a[i]y[i-1] +c[i]y[i] +b[i]y[i+1] = f[i] i=1..n-1 a[n]y[n-1] +c[n]y[n] = f[n]

member.name: T:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D
member.summary: 3D Tensor. The Tensor class realizes Linear Algebra Tensor 3D functions.

member.name: P:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.Item(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Item by indexes. NOTE: indexes begin with 1 NOT zero.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.GetRow(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets tensor's row. NOTE: row index begins with 1.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.SetRow(System.Int32,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D)
member.summary: Sets tensor's row. NOTE: row index begins with 1.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.GetColumn(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets tensor's column. NOTE: column index begins with 1.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.SetColumn(System.Int32,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D)
member.summary: Sets tensor's column. NOTE: column index begins with 1.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.ExtendSymmetric
member.summary: Makes the tensor SYMMETRIC by extending left bottom part to right top part.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.ExtendAntisymmetric
member.summary: Makes the tensor ANTISYMMETRIC by extending left bottom part to right top part with negation and SET diagonal values to 0.0.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.MakeDiagonal
member.summary: Makes the tensor DIAGONAL by setting nondiagonal elements to 0.0.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.Symmetric
member.summary: Calculates SYMMETRIC part of the tensor. S[i][j]=1/2(T[i][j]+T[j][i])

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.Antisymmetric
member.summary: Calculates ANTISYMMETRIC part of the tensor. A[i][j]=1/2(T[i][j]-T[j][i])

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.IsNaN
member.summary: One or more components are NaN.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.IsInfinite
member.summary: One or more components are Infinite.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.Transposed1Product(Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D,Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D)
member.summary: Product of the first TRANSPOSED tensor and the second.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.Transposed2Product(Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D,Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D)
member.summary: Product of the first tensor and the TRANSPOSED second.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.TransposedVectorProduct(Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D)
member.summary: Multiplies the transposed tensor on the vector.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.VectorTransposedProduct(Mathematics.LA.Vector3D,Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D)
member.summary: Multiplies the vector on the transposed tensor.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.Power(System.Int32)
member.summary: n-th power of the tensor. If n is positive, t^n=t*t*...*t (n times). If n is negative, the previous tensor inversed.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.SolveVectorSystem(System.Double,Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@)
member.summary: Solves vector linear system by precalculated tensor's determinant.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.PrincipalDirection(Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D,System.Double,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@)
member.summary: Calculates the direction of a principal value v. Theory for principal values V.Novatskiy, Theory of Elasticity, p. 24, p. 48. MARTIN H. SADD, ELASTICITY Theory, Applications, and Numerics, p. 12, p. 55.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D.PrincipalValuesSymmetric(Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D,System.Double,Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D@,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@)
member.summary: Calculates the principal values of a SYMMETRIC tensor and its 'directions'. Returnes six principal values in left-bottom tensor part. Note: because t may be not precise we have to introduce the precision to define if the equation can be solved.

member.name: T:Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D
member.summary: Antisymmetric 3D Tensor. Described by tree components under the main diagonal (left-bottom part). NOTE: Diagonal elements for antisymmetric tensors are always ZERO. Invariant1 and Invariant3 are always 0.0. Inversed tensor does not exist because determinant is always 0.0. Even power of antisymmetric tensor is a symmetric one and odd power is antisymmetric, so the function returns general tensor.

member.name: P:Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D.Item(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Tensor components by indexes (indexes begin with 1).

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D.SelfProduct
member.summary: Product of any antisymmetric tensor by itself is a symmetric tensor.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D.SymProduct(Mathematics.LA.STensor3D)
member.summary: Multiplies symmetric tensor by itself when it is known that the product is an antisymmetric tensor (when calculating power as an example).

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D.Power(System.Int32)
member.summary: n-th power of the tensor. WARNING: n>=0, for n less than 0 NaN result is returned because inversed tensor does NOT exist.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D.op_Multiply(Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D,Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D)
member.summary: Product of two antisymmetric tensors is not (in general) an antisymmetric tensor.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D.TransposedVectorProduct(Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D)
member.summary: Multiplies transposed tensor and a vector.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D.VectorTransposedProduct(Mathematics.LA.Vector3D,Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D)
member.summary: Multiplies a vector and transposed tensor.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D.Transposed1Product(Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D,Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D)
member.summary: Multiplies transposed first tensor by the second.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D.Transposed2Product(Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D,Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D)
member.summary: Multiplies the first tensor by transposed second.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D.MultiplyComponents(Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D,Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D)
member.summary: Multiplying components of two antisymmetric tensors leads to symmetric tensor with zero diagonal.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D.op_Explicit(Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D)~Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D
member.summary: Implicit conversion is not safe and can lead to stupid errors in code, so use explicit conversion operator.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D.op_Explicit(Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D)~Mathematics.LA.ATensor3D
member.summary: Implicit conversion is not safe and can lead to stupid errors in code, so use explicit conversion operator.

member.name: T:Mathematics.LA.DTensor3D
member.summary: Diagonal 3D Tensor. Described by three diagonal components.

member.name: P:Mathematics.LA.DTensor3D.Item(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Tensor component by indexes (indexes begin with 1)

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.DTensor3D.SolveVectorSystem(Mathematics.LA.DTensor3D,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@)
member.summary: Solves a linear system: [a]*{x}={b} by Cramer method. Returns TRUE if successful.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.DTensor3D.op_Explicit(Mathematics.LA.DTensor3D)~Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D
member.summary: Implicit conversion is not safe and can lead to stupid errors in code, so use explicit conversion operator.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.DTensor3D.op_Explicit(Mathematics.LA.DTensor3D)~Mathematics.LA.STensor3D
member.summary: Implicit conversion is not safe and can lead to stupid errors in code, so use explicit conversion operator.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.DTensor3D.op_Explicit(Mathematics.LA.STensor3D)~Mathematics.LA.DTensor3D
member.summary: Implicit conversion is not safe and can lead to stupid errors in code, so use explicit conversion operator.

member.name: T:Mathematics.LA.STensor3D
member.summary: Symmetric 3D Tensor. Described by six components - three diagonal and three under the main diagonal (left-bottom part). NOTE: Functions with transposed symmetric tensor are not needed because symmetric tensor and its transposed are the same.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.STensor3D.SetRow(System.Int32,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D)
member.summary: WARNING: setting row value implicitly affects other rows because data changed so, that the tensor keeps symmetric.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.STensor3D.SetColumn(System.Int32,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D)
member.summary: WARNING: setting column value implicitly affects other columns because data changed so, that the tensor keeps symmetric.

member.name: P:Mathematics.LA.STensor3D.Item(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Tensor's component by indexes (indexes begin with 1)

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.STensor3D.MakeDiagonal
member.summary: Makes tensor diagonal by setting nondiagonal elements to zero.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.STensor3D.SymmetricProduct(Mathematics.LA.STensor3D,Mathematics.LA.STensor3D)
member.summary: Special function for Symmetric Product when product of two symmetric tensors is also symmetric (for an example, tensor multiplied by itself).

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.STensor3D.Power(System.Int32)
member.summary: n-th power of the SYMMETRIC tensor. If n is positive, t^n=t*t*...*t (n times). If n is negative, the previous tensor inversed.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.STensor3D.op_Multiply(Mathematics.LA.STensor3D,Mathematics.LA.STensor3D)
member.summary: Product of two symmetric tensors is not (in general) a symmetric tensor.

member.summary: Solves a linear system: [a]*{x}={b} by Cramer method. Returns TRUE if successful.

member.summary: Solves a linear system: [a]*{x}={b} by Cramer method. Returns TRUE if successful.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.STensor3D.PrincipalDirection(Mathematics.LA.STensor3D,System.Double,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@)
member.summary: Calculates principal direction for principal value v.

member.name: M:Mathematics.LA.STensor3D.PrincipalValues(Mathematics.LA.STensor3D,System.Double,Mathematics.LA.STensor3D@,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D@)
member.summary: Calculates principal values and principal directions.

member.name: T:Mathematics.Fractions.Fraction
member.summary: Common Fraction class. Fraction is always reduced (after construction or any operation). A fraction can be consructed from any numerator and denominator (the later cannot be 0) but after construction the denominator is always positive (the sign returned in numerator).

member.summary: Private because the Fraction is always reduced

member.name: M:Mathematics.Functions.Factorial(System.Int32)
member.summary: Factorial function. NOT precise for big argument values.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Functions.RealEqual(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Compares two doubles for equality with given precision. Takes into account infinities (negative and positive) and NaNs. Do NOT confuse Actual and Expected values - it takes sense.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Functions.ComplexEqual(System.Numerics.Complex,System.Numerics.Complex)
member.summary: Compares two complex for equality with given precision. Takes into account infinities (negative and positive) and NaNs. Do NOT confuse Actual and Expected values - it takes sense.

member.name: T:Mathematics.CS.CylindricalSystem
member.summary: Cylindrical Coordinate System Kochin, Vector and Tensor analysis (p 195). x = rho*cos(phi) y = rho*sin(phi) z = z rho = sqrt(sqr(x)+sqr(y)) phi = arctan(y/x)

member.name: T:Mathematics.CS.SphericalSystem
member.summary: Spherical Coordinate System Kochin, Vector and Tensor analysis (p 195). Note : phi is the SECOND coordinate and theta is the THIRD one (differes from reference book) x = r*cos(phi)*sin(theta) y = r*sin(phi)*sin(theta) z = r*cos(theta) r = sqrt(sqr(x)+sqr(y)+sqr(z)) phi = arctan(y/x) theta = arctan(rho/z) (where rho = sqrt(sqr(x)+sqr(y)) )

member.name: T:Mathematics.CS.BaseSystem
member.summary: Note about all Coordinate Systems. Basic formulae for transformations between systems of different types (for example Cartesian-Cylindrical) are from Kochin, Vector and Tensor analysis (p 195). All systems are RIGHT-handed. There are three types of Coordinate System transformation relative to Global (World) coordanate space: translation of the origin of the system, rotation about the system axes and scaling along the system axes. The order of transformation is Scaling->Rotation->Translation. There are three types of Coordinates and Vectors Coordinate Systems deal with: Global - data of position or vector in Global (World) space. Relative - data of position or vector in CARTESIAN system such that the origin and basis of the system are subjected to all transformations. Local - data of position or vector in NATIVE components (for example r phi z in Cylindrical system). The origin of Local space is the same as Relative. There are Position, Vector and Normal transformations. Positions are subjected to all types of transformations - Scaling, Rotation and Translations. Vectors and Normals are not subjected to Translation (it does not matter for vectors). Vector transformations differs from Normal transformations by Scaling. Vectors scale as Vx*Sx Vy*Sy Vz*Sz but Normals scale as Nx/Sx Ny/Sy Nz/Sz. The reason is when the surface is scaled say in direction x by 2 (surface is longer in x direction) the normal to the surface gets shorter in x direction. See also MARTIN H. SADD, ELASTICITY. Theory, Applications, and Numerics, appendix B. From the book: CS Rotation matrix [Q] is such that {v}^=[Q]{v}, where {v} is a vector from original CS and {v}^ in transformed (rotated) CS. Each i-th row of the matrix is the coordinates of i-th ort {e}^ of the transformed CS in original one. NOTE: HERE THE ROTATION TENSOR IS SUCH THAT {v}=[Q]{v}^, THAT IS OPPOSITE TO THE BOOK (AND ALL OTHER SOURCES).

member.name: M:Mathematics.CS.BaseSystem.MoveTo(Mathematics.LA.Vector3D)
member.summary: Moves sytem centre to v position.

member.name: T:Mathematics.CS.CurvilinearOrthogonalSystem
member.summary: Curvilinear ortogonal system introduces transformations using local basis of the system. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curvilinear_coordinates.

member.name: T:Mathematics.CS.ParametricSystem
member.summary: Parametric System is so that its geometry depends on parameters (see toroidal as an example).

member.name: M:Mathematics.CS.Transformations.RotationTensors3D(Mathematics.LA.Vector3D,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D,Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D@,Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D@,Mathematics.LA.Tensor3D@)
member.summary: Forms Rotation Tensors by calculated sin and cos of rotation angles. See note about rotation tensor. The tensor is such, that it represents the transformation matrix to get original coordinates from transformed ones that is {v}=[t]{v}^ (where {v}^ is the vector in rotated CS).

member.name: M:Mathematics.CS.Transformations.RotationTensor3D(Mathematics.LA.Vector3D)
member.summary: Calculates Rotation Tensor by rotation angles. Each angles vector component is the angle in radians of rotation about the corresponding axis if the rotation is carried out subsequently about the first, the second and the third axis.

member.name: M:Mathematics.CS.Transformations.RotationTensor3D(Mathematics.LA.Vector3D,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D,Mathematics.LA.Vector3D)
member.summary: Calculates Rotation Tensor by axes orts. Orts must be normalized vectors. Rotation Tensor is nothing but Basis Vector coordinates of the transformed (rotated) CS in the original CS. Fletcher Dunn, 3D Math Primer for Graphics and Game Development, p 93. NOTE: We must set each vector in the tensor's COLUMN NOT ROW because of our Rotation Tensor treatement (see note about rotation tensor).

member.name: T:Mathematics.CS.ProlateSpheroidalSystem
member.summary: Prolate Spheroidal Coordinate system Note : phi is the SECOND coordinate and theta is the THIRD one (differes from reference article http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prolate_spheroidal_coordinates) Direct transformation x = a*sinh(mu)*cos(phi)*sin(theta) Where a is the parameter of the system. y = a*sinh(mu)*sin(phi)*sin(theta) mu=0..infinity, phi=0..2*Pi z = a*cosh(mu)*cos(theta) theta=0..Pi (NOTE: theta - ?) Inverse transformation mu = arccosh((d1+d2)/(2 a)) Where rho^2 = x^2 + y^2, phi = arctan(y/x) d1^2 = rho^2 + (z+a)^2, d2^2 = rho^2 + (z-a)^2 theta = arccos((d1-d2)/(2 a)) SIGN OF theta IS always '+' (theta=0..Pi).

member.name: T:Mathematics.CS.OblateSpheroidalSystem
member.summary: Oblate Spheroidal Coordinate system Note : phi is the SECOND coordinate and theta is the THIRD one (differes from reference article http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oblate_spheroidal_coordinates) Direct transformation x = a*cosh(mu)*cos(phi)*cos(theta) Where a is the parameter of the system. y = a*cosh(mu)*sin(phi)*cos(theta) mu=0..infinity, phi=-Pi..Pi z = a*sinh(mu)*sin(theta) theta=-Pi/2..Pi/2 (NOTE: theta differes from Spherical CS) Inverse transformation mu = arccosh((d1+d2)/(2a)) Where rho^2 = x^2 + y^2, phi = arctan(y/x) d1^2 = (rho+a)^2 + z^2, d2^2 = (rho-a)^2 + z^2 theta = arccos((d1-d2)/(2a)) Sigh of mu is always '+', SIGN OF theta IS AS OF z.

member.name: T:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialI
member.summary: Legendre Polynomial of the first kind. Literature for The Associated Legendre polynomial of the first kind P: Janke (Yanke) Special functions. Moscow, 1964. p. 162.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialI.dPn(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the first derivative of P[n](x) by x

member.name: M:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialI.d2Pn(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the second derivative of P[n](x) by x

member.name: M:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialI.Pnm(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates P[n,m](x) for [-1 1] Note : there is a problem with P[n,m] calculation for high powers n (n>40). It is due to rounding in float pointing operations in sum calculation. Value is not precise near abs(x)=1.0. The more power the more length of "wrong" values. For example, with n=50 the length is 0.2, that is for n=50 the value of P[n,m](x) is precise for abs(x) less than 0.8. (check is P[n,0](x)=P[n](x))

member.name: M:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialI.dPnm(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the first derivative of P[n,m](x) by x (for [-1 1])

member.name: M:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialI.PnmDSqrtX(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates P[n,m](x)/(1.0-x^2)^(0.5) taking into account singularity for (1.0-x^2)=0

member.name: M:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialI.PnmDSqrtX1(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Calculates P[n,m](x) and P[n,m](x)/(1.0-x^2)^(0.5) taking into account singularity for (1.0-x^2)=0 by precalculated sqrtx = (1-x^2)^(1/2).

member.name: M:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialI.PnmDSqrtX2(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Calculates P[n,m](x) and P[n,m](x)/(1.0-x^2)^(0.5) and P[n,m](x)/(1.0-x^2) taking into account singularity for (1.0-x^2)=0 by precalculated sqrtx = (1-x^2)^(1/2).

member.name: T:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialII
member.summary: Legendre Polynomial of the second kind. Literature for The Associated Legendre polynomial of the second kind Q: Janke (Yanke) Special functions. Moscow, 1964. p. 162.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialII.dQn(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the first derivative of Q[n](x) by x

member.name: M:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialII.d2Qn(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the second derivative of Q[n](x) by x

member.name: M:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialII.QnmDSqrtX(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates Q[n,m](x)/(1.0-x^2)^(0.5) with no singularity for (1.0-x^2)=0

member.name: M:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialII.dQnm(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the first derivative of Q[n,m](x) by x (for [-1 1])

member.name: M:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialISimple.dPnm(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: TODO : check the precision of the calculation for high n! It canNOT be more precise then P[n,m] calculation due to using the same sum function that gives the error.

member.name: T:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialIFast
member.summary: FAST P[n,m](x) calculation realization (based on precalculation of all coefficients not dependant on x)

member.name: F:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialIFast.fnmPowPrefixes
member.summary: prefixes with powers in the sum of [n,m]

member.name: F:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialIFast.fMaxnmCalculated
member.summary: Max Power of [n,m] the data calculated for

member.name: F:Mathematics.Special.LegendrePolynomialIFast.MaxPrecisePower
member.summary: This const based on the current precise calculation for P[n,m] but is not a strong restriction on the max power of polynomials.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Functions.Sort(System.Int32,System.Double[])
member.summary: Sorts the array. order: -1 descending, 1 ascending.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Functions.PowerMean(System.Int32,System.Double[])
member.summary: Power mean for common power cases. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean#Power_mean -1: Harmonic 0: Geometric 1: Arithmetic 2: Quadratic

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Functions.Sample(System.Double[],System.Double)
member.summary: Returns all different samples (sorted in ascending order) in the array.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Functions.Frequency(System.Double[],System.Double)
member.summary: Returns number of different samples (sorted in ascending order) in the array.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Functions.Histogram(System.Double[],System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates histogram of values with n subintervals.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Functions.Values(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double[])
member.summary: Values from array in the interval [x1..x2].

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Functions.Items(System.Double[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Array items. n - item numbers. NOTE: number of items can be greater than number of values and items can be included in the result many times.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Functions.Sort(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double[0:,0:])
member.summary: Sorts the matrix' rows by values in the column. column: column index to sort. order: -1 descending, 1 ascending.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Functions.PowerMean(System.Int32,System.Double[0:,0:])
member.summary: Power mean by matrix' rows. -1: Harmonic 0: Geometric 1: Arithmetic 2: Quadratic

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Functions.Items(System.Double[0:,0:],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Items from matrix' rows. n - item numbers. /// NOTE: number of items can be greater than number of values and items can be included in the result many times. WARNING: all indexes in 'n' must be valid (as the number of result matrix rows = Length(n))

member.name: T:Mathematics.Statistics.Distribution
member.summary: Base abstract class for probability distribution.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Distribution.GeneratePDF(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates the sequence of n PDF values on the interval.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Distribution.GenerateCDF(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates the sequence of n CDF values on the interval.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Distribution.GenerateQuantile(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates the sequence of n Quantile values on the interval.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Distribution.Random
member.summary: Random number. NOTE: Default implementation is using uniform random number [0..1] and applying the inversed CDF (Quantile) function to it https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_transform_sampling. Can be overriden for special cases and when the Quantile is undefined.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Distribution.GenerateRnd(System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates the sequence of n Randon values.

member.name: M:Mathematics.Statistics.Distribution.GenerateRnd(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates the sequence of n Random values on the interval.
